CDD as a Ser vice SW-C Introduction Sub-Layers Services Layer ECU Abstraction Layer Complex Device Drivers (CDD) Micro Controller Abstraction Layer (MCAL) COM Stack basics COM Module PduR Module IPDU-M Module FR/ CAN/ LIN Stack Basics Hardware Configuration Memory Stack basics NVRAM Manager Module NVRAM Manager as a Service SW-C MemIf module Flash/ Eeprom Stack Introduction Fundamentals of AUTOSAR OS Extensions to and restrictions on OSEK OS OS Tasks OS counters OS Alarms OS Events OS Scheduler and Schedule tables Schedule table Synchronization ISRs and types OS Resources OS Protection OS Hooks Services to SchM OS Scalability classes Basics of Measurement and Calibration XCP module Calibration with FR/ CAN Interaction of XCP module Introduction RTE Concepts Calibration
AUTOSAR - AUTomotive Open System ARchitecture 

Consortium found in 2002 by auto manufacturers later joined by suppliers and silicon chip providers 

Initiative supported by auto industry to develop a de-facto open standard for automotive E/ E architectures 

Focuses to specify standard architecture for system software 

Software development based on function based approach 

Aims to improve performance, safety and environmental electronic systems
AUTOSAR consortium consists of three members identified based on their initiatives 

The members will be given appropriate rights and allocated to the various duties 

Members of AUTOSAR 
 - Core partners 
 - Premium members 
 - Associate members 

Support members of AUTOSAR 
 - Development members 
 - Attendees
To have a common requirements/ understanding between auto stake holders 

Create a standard core for industry on basic functions where innovative functions are built on top of it 

HW and SW are widely independent. With parallel developments, reduces the development time and costs 

Re-use of software increases at OEMs and suppliers. Improve the quality and efficiency 

Faster development of auto software thru commercial design tools 

Software integration from multiple vendors at ease
Follows ‘Component’ style 

Interaction between SW-Cs and to BSW thru RTE 

Follows the methodology to interact between SW-Cs 

SW-Cs shall be different types identified as on need basis 

Each SW-C has a part of functionality of an application
Acts as middle layer to abstract SW-Cs from BSW 

Makes application layer independent of BSW layer 

Implements communication mechanisms to interact within SW-Cs and between SW-C and BSW 

Internal behavior of all SW-Cs in ECU will be configured and implemented here
BSW has all the modules needed for application 

AUTOSAR defines the specifications for the all the modules and their integration 

Has modules to interact directly with hardware 

Has OS for scheduling purposes
The communication happens thru ports those implements interfaces as per communication mechanism 

Each SW-C will have ports to interact 

Communication thru RTE 

The communication in BSW is abstracted to the SW-Cs
AUTOSAR supports 3 configuration classes 

Pre-Compile time 
 - The software controlled by configuration at pre-compile time 
 - Need to re-make the software upon changes 
 - Support only parameters of Pre-Compile time 

Link-time 
 - The constant configuration data can be supplied as object code at link time (Warranty reasons, IP protection etc.) 
 - Need to re-link the software upon changes 
 - Support the parameters of Pre-Compile time and Link time 

Post-build time 
 - The constant configuration data can be supplied/ loaded at any time at known fixed entry point 
 - Load new configuration data at any time 
 - Support the parameters of all above
Has 3 Conformance Classes 
 - ICC1 
 - ICC2 
 - ICC3 

The classes are based on 
 - AUTOSAR compliancy 
 - Standardizationsacross different layers 
 - Standardizationsacross sub-layers, clusters, stacks and modules etc.
Supports fault handling and reporting 

The possible errors/ failures AUTOSAR addresses are 
 - Hardware errors 
 - System errors 
 - Software errors 

Addressing the errors 
 - Development stages 
 - Reported to DET module 
 - Feature can be switched OFF after development stage 
 - Optional feature can be switched ON/ OFF 
 - Production stages 
 - Reported to DEM module 
 - Feature shall be always ON to store and retrieve the permanent errors 
 - Errors can be retrieved thru external tools
Provides services for Diagnostics 

Interacts over LIN/ CAN/ FR with external tools 

Supports LIN/ CAN/ FR communication 

Interacts with BSW directly, SWCs thru RTE to set/ get the data 

Interacts with fault memory 

Handles variety of diagnostic protocols DCM functionalities 

Handles diagnostic communication 

Interacts with application 

Interacts with ComM to handle communication states 

Handles tester presence service 

Security level handling 

Managing diagnostics sessions 

Handling various diagnostic protocols 

Service response handling 

Realized as Ser vice SW-C Provides services to 
 - Process and access fault data 
 - Snapshots fault data at occurrence 
 - Accessto freeze frame data 

Provide fault data to DCM 

Accesses the NV memories to handle fault data 

Enable/ Disable fault logging 

Fault reactions handled by FIM module 

Realized as Service SW-C More features of DEM 

Event combination (Optional feature) 

Pre-storage of Freeze frame data 

Supports extended data records 

DEM operation cycles 

NV memory access 

De-bouncing algorithms for events 
 - Count er/ Time/ Frequency based 
 - DTC fault detection counter 

Realized as Ser vice SW-C BSW report the errors detected at development stages 

The report collects 
 - Module occurred 
 - Function occurred 
 - Error classification 

The functionality is implementation specific 

Possible use cases are 
 - Count ing the errors 
 - Log calls 

Realized as Ser vice SW-C
Control the fault reaction functionalities 

Functionalities check the inhibit conditions before executing 

Event status information acts as inhibit conditions 

Example 
 – A sensor can have inhibit conditions. Upon failure, the functionality checks the inhibit condition and stops executing 

Supports summarized event 

Realized as Service SW-C
ECU has states between power-up to shutdown 

States on ECU, communication, network levels etc. 

For smooth operation, these states has to be transitioned 

States has to synchronize 

In AUTOSAR we have 
 - ECU states: Managed by EcuM 
 - Wdg states: Managed by WdgM 
 - Communication states: Managed by ComM 

Application shall have their states and logic
First module to be initialized in AUTOSAR software 

Initializes the ECU state machine 

Initializes all the modules 

Application need to request RUN/ SHUTDOWN states 

Handles sleep and wake-up functionalities 

Performs wake-up validation 

Handles initialization and shutdown procedure thru state machine 

Handles various shutdown targets
EcuM States 

EcuM initialization starts the state machine 
 - STARTUP states 
 - STARTUP I 
 - Start up state before OS started 
 - Modules independent of OS are initialized 
 - Fundamental needs for ECU (Mcu, Det etc.) are initialized 
 - STARTUP II 
 - Start up state after OS started 
 - Modules dependant on OSare initialized 
 - Modules with schedulable functions shall be initialized
After STARTUP states, the state machine moves to 
 - RUN states 
 - RUN 
 - Execution of application tasks 
 - User has to request RUN state 
 - If valid RUN request, ECU stays in RUN state 
 - If no RUN request with in predefined t ime, moves to POSTRUN state 
 - State shall be left if user releases the request 
 - POSTRUN 
 - If user has any post activities, need to request POSTRUN before releasing RUN 
 - If RUN request, goes back to RUN state 
 - State shall be left if user releases the request 
 - If released, moves to SHUTDOWN state After RUN states, the state machine moves to 
 - SHUTDOWN states 
 - PREP SHUTDOWN 
 - Application is de-initialized 
 - No network 
 - If shutdown target is SLEEP, goes to GOSLEEP state else GOOFF I 
 - GO SLEEP 
 - Settings to made to go the sleep phase 
 - If valid wakeup, clear and enable the interrupts and moves to WAKEUP state 
 - Save NV data 
 - Enable wake-up sources 
 - Move Wdg state to SLEEP 
 - For data safety, the RAM integrity algorithms shall be created 
 - GOOFF I 
 - De-initialize all modules dependant on OS 
 - Set Wdg mode to shutdown 
 - Save NV data 
 - Set RESET as shutdown target, if any pending wakeup events found 
 - Shut down OS 
 - GOOFF II 
 - If Shut down target is RESET, Mcu performs RESET else SHUTDOWN
SLEEP state 
 - SLEEP state achieved from GOSLEEP if there are no wake up events 
 - No code is executed in this state as micro is halted 
 - If any wakeup found on the way to SLEEP, moves to WAKEUP state 
 - Wakeup sources should be enabled in SLEEP state 
 - Upon a valid wakeup, WAKEUP state shall be achieved WAKEUP states 
 - WAKEUP I 
 - Restore MCU and Wdg states to normal 
 - Re-initialize the wakeup source drivers 
 - Actual wake source should set an wakeup event 
 - Disable wakeup sources 
 - Unlock the scheduler 
 - WAKEUP VALIDATION 
 - Validate the pending wakeup events 
 - Eliminate false wakeups 
 - WAKEUP REACTION 
 - Action to be taken on successful wakeup validation 
 - Move to RUN, Shut down state etc..are possibilities 
 - WAKEUP II 
 - Initialize the diagnostics 
 - Indicate the modes to RTE EcuM as a Service SW-C 

EcuM provides predefined ports to connect to application 
 - Release/ Request RUN state 
 - Release/ Request POST RUN state 
 - Select / get shutdown target 
 - Select / get application modes
Configuration 

EcuM SWC description can be arrived with 
 - Port interfaces 
 - S/R interfaces for getting modes 
 - C/S interfaces for predefined ports 
 - Modes 
 - Mode ports and interfaces 
 - Data types 
 - Mode Declaration Gr oup with all ECU modes 
 - All types of EcuM 
 - Runnables 
 - All EcuM services 
 - EcuM services as server operations
To supervise the reliability of software execution 

Provides alive-supervision of application 

Trigger the hardware Wdg 

Can supervise multiple entities 

Takes the decision on global supervision 

Each SE has to provide live indications to WdgM 

EcuM sync Wdg to ECU states
Wdg Modes 

Supports different modes 

Each mode is defined by 
 - Set of active SEs and their alive supervision parameters 
 - Set of Wdgs to be tr iggered and their triggering parameters 

Source of activation for cyclic activities of WdgM 

Configur able number of modes 

Different modes used for phases of ECU 

Upon errors, entry for DEM is available Contr ols BSW related to communication 

Processes bus communication requests 

Abstract the communication hardware and software 

Enable/ Disable the communication signals/ messages 

Highest state results upon multiple requests from same user 

Cover s FR, CAN and LIN buses 

Manages Network and state managers 

Manages bus errors 

Realized as Ser vice SWC Bus error management 

Network start indication for specific bus channel 

Switch to FULL COM on this indication
CDD – Complex Device Drivers 

The devices with need of complex processing time 

Standard/ Non-standard from AUTOSAR 

No need to follow any standard within CDDs but AUTOSAR way to outside software 

The scaled AUTOSAR driver can also be a CDD 

A highly compact IP design/ algorithm software can fit as CDD 

Non-AUTOSAR communication drivers
Interaction with in CDD is implementation specific 

Interaction from CDD to application is thru RTE 

No abstraction layers between RTE, CDD and Hardware 

Possible to interact with BSW modules 

Shall use OS for its schedulable entities 

EcuM shall initialize 

Shall use OS for interrupts 

Shall use SPI for external communication 

Realized as Ser vice SW-C
Anything not available in AUTOSAR standards 

Anything complex – Complex Sensors and Actuators 

Electrical interfacing – Motor controls and actuators 

Complex algorithm processing – DSP processors for Camer a/ Radar etc. 

IP ASICs 

Protocols - I2C, IP protocols etc. 

Cr ypto hardware services 

DEShardware services
Realized as Ser vice SWC 

SWC description can be made with below and imported in application 
 - CDD data types 
 - CDD APIs 
 - CDD schedulable functions 
 - CDD server operations 
 - PDAVs for CDD APIs 
 - Mode declaration groups etc.
Executes the functional part of application needs 

BSW offers 
 - Communication services 
 - Diagnosticsservices 
 - Calibration services 
 - Memory services 
 - Micro Controller services 
 - OSser vices 
 - Mode Management services 
 - Complex Device Drivers 

Access to hardware 

Abstract application from hardware for more portability 

Hardware independent BSW parts can be re-used completely
BSW has below main sub layers 
 - Service layer 
 - ECU Abstraction layer 
 - Complex Device Drivers (CDD) 
 - Micro Controller Abstraction Layer (MCAL)
Offer s basic services required for BSW and applications 

Services include 
 - System services 
 - Memory services 
 - Communication services Abstracts ECU hardware 

Abstracts MCAL from Ser vice layer 

Interfaces external devices 

Offer s various abstraction services 
 - Onboar d device abstraction 
 - Memory hardware abstraction 
 - Communication hardware abstraction 
 - IO hardware abstraction
Enables to integrate special purpose functionality not specified in AUTOSAR 

Specific devices with high timing constraints 

Enables a way for migration 

CDDs hardware access is abstraction free 

CDDs interact directly to RTE to less the latency Lowest layer access to hardware 

Access to micro controller peripherals, on-board modules 
 - Micro controller drivers 
 - Memory drivers 
 - Communication drivers 
 - IO drivers
For Vehicle network communication, FR/ CAN/ LIN stacks available in AUTOSAR 

A stack of modules i.e. comm driver, abstraction module, Tp operation, routing, unpacking/ packing of signals etc. makes a complete COM Stack 

COM managers (states, NM etc.), Calibration are also included to enhance
A physical representation of a high numerical level data 

Signal types 

Have a start position and initial value and updated to PDU directly 

Group Signal 
 - A signal depending on other signals 
 - Data has to be updated in shadow fir st 

Signal group 
 - A set of group signals packed in a complex signal 
 - May have 0…N group signals inside 
 - Data has to be updated to PDU from Shadow
PDU (Protocol Data Unit) 
 – A data unit packed with set of signals/ group signals 
 - PDU can’t have both signals and group signals at a time 

PDU Group 
 - A group of zero or more PDUs or PDU groups 
 - A set of PDUs/ PDU Groups transmission/ reception can be controlled by specific PDU Group start/ stop 
 - Limited to 32 in an ECU
All the PDUs info is available in EcuC 

Modules access EcuC for PDU properties
Top BSW module communicating to RTE 

Provides services to application thru RTE and rest of BSW COM Stack 

Functionalities of COM module includes 
 - Signal and Message access 
 - Both Signal and Message access and Gat eways by COM 
 - Packing and un-packing of signals to/ from messages 
 - Deadline monitoring 
 - Filter based reception 
 - EndianNess handling 
 - Communication modes 
 - Signal transfer modes 
 - PDU Transmission modes 
 - Signal indication modes 
 - Immediate 
 - Deferred 
 - Communication transmission control (start/ stop of PDU groups) Applied at reception 

Removes unwanted data and their processing 

Supports signed types also. No support for complex types 

Also used for Transmission Mode Selection (TMS)
COM supports 2 modes for communication 
 - Modes for Signals (Transfer properties) 
 - TRIGGERED 
 - PENDING 
 - Modes for PDUs (Transmission modes) 
 - PERIODIC 
 - DIRECT/ N-TIMES 
 - MIXED 
 - NONE
Suppor ts for both interrupt and polling methods 

2 modes 
 - IMMEDIATE 
 - DEFERRED
Communication can be enabled/ disabled for specific PDUs 

PDUs can be logically grouped as groups and then controlled 

Transmission control by state managers thru COM 

2 levels of IPDU-Group depth allowed
PduR Module placed between COM and FR/ CAN/ LIN Stack 

Provides interfaces to communication related modules 

Functionalities of PduR module are 

Routing functionality 
 - Gateway functionality 
 - Minimum Routing capability 
 - Multi Cast operation 
 - Zero Cost operation Only predefined Pre-Compile and Link-time configurations possible 

No routing tables 

Optional feature
MultiCast Routing 

MultiCast Gatew ay Routing Eliminate PduR module actual functionality 

PduR hand shakes between upper and lower layers with zero latency 

PduR just maps the interfaces of source and destination modules
Enables the multiplexing of PDUs 

Possible only with static configuration 

Multiplexed PDU will have Static and Dynamic parts 

Static part will have layout as configured 

The dynamic part may be multiplexed as configured and sent using same PDU Id Deals with FR/ CAN/ LIN services 

A stack includes 
 - <X>Driver 
 - <X>Internal Driver 
 - <X>External Driver interfaced with SPI 
 - <X>If module 
 - LIN Tp is integrated with LIN If 
 - <X>Tp module 
 - No separate LIN Tp 
 - <X>Sm module 
 - <X>Nm module 

Over view of these modules are in next slides Tp Operation 

Segments large data into PDU size 

Re-assemble segmented PDUs into large chunk 

Maintains a protocol with flow control 

Transmit cancellation 

Uses Timer resources


Example: 
PduR trying to send 50bytes
State Management 

Handles communication states 

Aligns the transceiver modes based on application needs 

Control the PDU groups 

Answers the bus errors (bus-off) by moving into safe states 

Based on requested communication mode, the transmission/ reception can be stopped and started 

Handles timeout for Deadline monitoring




Abstraction modules 

Abstract CAN hardware 

Control the CAN driver and transceiver 

Control the external CAN hardware interface thru SPI 

Handles transmit confirmations 

Handles reception, bus-off and wake-up notifications 

Configure software mailboxes with BASIC/ FULL fashion 

Multiple CAN driver support
Network Management 

Co-ordinate between network states 

Realized thru voting mechanism. Consolidation of ECUs votes on periodic basis results in taking the decision 

Able to detect all present nodes and nodes which are ready to sleep 

Supports bus-sleep and wake-up mechanisms 

Partial networking not supported 

Has the below modes 
 - Network mode 
 - Prepare Bus-Sleep mode 
 - Bus-Sleep mode The respective HW (FR/ CAN/ LIN) has to be configured with 
 - Mailboxes 
 - HW filters 
 - ISR/ Polling based communication 
 - Transceiver configuration 


Mailboxes configuration 

CAN controller has predefined HW mailboxes 

Each mailbox associated with HW filter to pass through 

<X>If module can have SW mailboxes for the respective HW mailboxes 

HW mailboxes can be assigned in BASIC/ FULL CAN fashion
HW filters 

 Each HW mailbox associated with HW filter 

HW filter helps to send/ receive only filtered message with matching ID in FULL CAN 

In BASIC CAN, a filter can allow messages with the range of IDs passed thru the filter 


 ISR/Polling based message access 

With ISRs, the reception of data in HW mailbox is tr iggered with ISR 

If indications/ notifications are configured, they will be tr iggered 

Bus-Off and Wake-up processing can by done by ISR tr iggering 

With Polling, CanIf has to poll for reception 

The schedulable functions of CAN has to take care of the data and notifications
Transceiver configuration 

Conver ts bus logical signals to physical signals 

Able to detect bus errors 

Sleep, Wake-up etc. modes shall be configured 

IO pins used for transceiver shall be configurable 

Always powered-on to detect the wake-ups
The Stack of modules for memory access 

Flash and Eeprom are available in AUTOSAR 

Stack includes memory manager, abstraction and memories 

External memories can be interfaced with SPI 

Provides synchronous/ asynchronous services to memory access
Types of memories 

The Memory Stack deals with 
 - ROM 
 - RAM 
 - NV Memory (Flash/ Eeprom) 

ROM memory exists in FLASH 

RAM memory as usual in RAM 

NV memory (Flash and Eeprom) divided into pages, blocks etc. 

Few differences are below
Manages NV memories 

Synchronous and asynchronous services for handling NV data 

Services to read/ write all blocks at once 

Protection facility for the NV layout 

Uses abstraction to select the specific memory 

Uses CRC module 

Manages the memory as NV blocks Memory blocks 

Memory Stack deals with blocks 
 - ROM block 
 - RAM block 
 - NV block 
 - Administrative block 

ROM block resides in Flash 

NV block resides in Flash/ Eeprom 

RAM and NV blocks shall have CRC (optional) 

Administrative block reside in RAM having block index for dataset NV blocks



Types of memory blocks 

3 types of blocks 
 - Native block 
 - Redundant block 
 - Native block + Its redundant copy 
 - Dataset block 
 - N number of Native blocks arranged as arrays and accessed with index Block management types 

A single NVM block can associate with 
 - Its ROM block 
 - Its RAM block 
 - Its Administrative block 

Job Processing 

Supports priority based job processing 

Maintains 2 queues 
 - Immediate Write jobs 
 - Rest of immediate read/ erase jobs 

Immediate write job has high priority Services for NV data access 

Three API configuration classes 
 - API configuration class 1 
 - Get error and Set block status 
 - ReadAll, WriteAll, CancelWr iteAll 
 - API configuration class 2 
 - Class 1 + 
 - Dataset block support 
 - Read block, Write block and Restoring block defaults 
 - API configuration class 3 
 - Class 2 + 
 - Block protection 
 - Erase and Invalidate the block Read block strategy 

ROM defaults are read at the very first journey 

If NV block data available, 
 - RAM mirror updated from native NV block 
 - RAM mirror updated from redundant block upon its native block read failure 
 - RAM mirror updated with ROM defaults 

If invoked with a valid ptr, returns the ptr with NV block 

If invoked with NULL, the NV data copied to its RAM block 

Notifications configurable for asynchronous read calls



Write block strategy 

If any changes in RAM block data, updated to its NV block 

No change in RAM block contents results no writing 

Notifications configurable for asynchronous write calls ReadAll blocks strategy 

ReadAll blocks synchronously/ asynchronously 

Happens mostly at ECU start-up 

Blocks need to be configured for this feature 

The data is loaded to their respective RAM mirrors 

If corrupted/ errors 
 - Redundant block data are loaded 
 - ROM defaults are loaded 

Notification configurable for asynchronous calls



WriteAll blocks strategy 

WriteAll blocks synchronously/ asynchronously 

Happens mostly at ECU shutdown 

Blocks need to be configured for this feature 

RAM mirrors are written back upon changes 

Supports aborting on-going WriteAll operation Configuration of NVRAM blocks 

Configure NVRAM blocks as required 

Each NVRAM block has properties of 
 - CRCused 
 - Block management type 
 - Block length 
 - RAM and ROM blocks reference 
 - Select for ReadAll() 
 - Notification 
 - Target block reference 

Essential blocks to be configured 
 - Multi block 
 - Native block read/ written by ReadAll and WriteAll 
 - No RAM/ ROM reference 
 - No target reference 
 - Config ID block 
 - Redundant block holding ConfigID for NV memory layout 
 - Integrity check on flashed ConfigID vs configured CompiledConfigID while ReadAll() DatasetSelectionBits 

LSB bits used to index the datasets 

LSB bits used are from NvMBlockBaseNumber 

TargetBlockNumber = (NvMBlockBaseNumber << DatasetSelectionBits)
Application interacts with NVRAM thru RTE 

Interaction thru AUTOSAR interfaces thru RTE 

Notifications issued to SW-Cs for Async requests Configuration 

SW-C description has to be arrived with 
 - Data types 
 - NVRAM types, return values etc. 
 - Port s 
 - C/ Sservice ports 
 - Port interface 
 - C/ Sinterface 
 - NVRAM servicesas operations 
 - Internal Behavior 
 - RTE events 
 - Events for tr iggering 
 - Runnable entities 
 - NVRAM servicesas Runnable entities tr iggered concurrently Abstracts from lower memory layers 

Diverts NVRAM Manager requests to target blocks 

No specific initialization 

Services to support/ abstract NVRAM services Abstracts physical memories to above layers 

Physical addressing happens 

Block number calculated as per NVRAM configuration 

Physical Flash/ Eeprom layout configuration. Enables interrupts 

Manages read/ write cycles 

Services to read/ write/ compare/ status blocks Notifications configured for Async requests 

Configured for multi/ single blocks 

Job error/ end notifications possible
External memory interfacing 

Possibility of interfacing external Eeprom 

Ext memories are interfaced thru SPI 

Ext Eeprom driver available at Abstraction layer 

Needs additional modules and configuration (DMA, GPIO pins for SPI etc.)
The schedulable entities are scheduled by OS 

OS supports time, event based scheduling 

Mostly OS is statically configured 

Provides protection schemes for safety and hw resources 

Supports Single/ Multi core OS 

Handles deadlines 

Vector table to register interrupts 

Suppor ts multiple OS-Applications 

Hook functions for tracing 

Provides services to work with basic OS objects 

Suppor ts Confor mance classes for different applications 

Provides standardized interfaces 

Provides different scalability classes and error checking Fundamentals of AUTOSAR OS 

Configur ed and scaled statically 

Provides different scheduling methods 

Protection features 

OSEK OS is the basis for AUTOSAR OS 

Handling interrupts and priorities 

Suppor ts schedulable tables for synchronization 

OS-Applications 

Scalability classes 

Hook functions for tracing 

Error checking Extensions to and restrictions on OSEK OS 

AUTOSAR OS doesn’t support internal communication 

Portability improvement with defined behavior 

Extended level of error checking 

Star tOS() shall not return 

Defined process of OS shutdown 
 - Disabling all the interrupts 
 - Entering into endless loop 

Availability of interrupts at OS start and OS shutdown 

Improved the actions on Alarm expiry 
 - Incrementing the software counter 

Dedicated service to increment the counters
OS Tasks 

Application synchronizes by executing tasks 

Scheduled entities by OS 

Executed concurrently or asynchronously 

Tasks has priority 

Tasks triggered by alarms or scheduled expiry points 

Multiple activation of tasks possible 

OS Services available for scheduling 

2 Types 
 - Basic Task 
 - Have finite time of execution 
 - No waiting allowed 
 - Can have ‘n’ number of basic tasks for application synchronization 
 - Pre-emption based on priority Extended tasks 

Tasks may/ may not return 

Can wait forever 

On waiting state, the processor switches to next priority task 

Consumes more resources
OS Counters 

Represented as value incremented at constant speed 

Measured as ‘ticks’ 

Links to Alarms and configures action on its expiry 

Can be hardware or software timer 

Ser vice to operate on counters 

At least one counter is needed 

Configured statically 

Counter actions 
 - Triggering interrupts 
 - Triggering alarms etc. OS Alarms 

For time based tr iggering 

Uses counters 

Can be AutoStar t 

2 types 
 - Cyclic 
 - Non-Cyclic 

Alarm actions 
 - Activate the tasks 
 - Set events 
 - Increment the counter 
 - Alarm call-back 

Multiple alarms can use same counter OS Events 

Connecting synchronization points 

Available for extended tasks only 

Application events possible to sync its logic 

Services offered to work with events directly 

Events may occur on 
 - Expiry of t imer/ alarm 
 - Successful of transmission/ reception of signal/ message 

Rules and restrictions 
 - All tasks can set the events 
 - The owner of task only clears/ wait for event. Exception for extended tasks 
 - ISR and Basic tasks can’t wait for event 

Events are key to release from waiting state OS Scheduler 

Schedules the tasks as per scheduling schemes 

The tasks has to be activated to schedule them 

State transitions 
 - On activation, task moved to Ready state 
 - Priority and scheme resolved, task moved to Running state 
 - Waiting for event inside, task moved to Waiting state and schedule next priority task 
 - Higher priority task arrived, move existing task to Ready and new task to Running 
 - Event occurred in Waiting state, move the running and waiting tasks to Ready state 
 - Task terminated, task moved to Suspended state 

Scheduler tr iggered either 
 - By alarm expiry 
 - Schedule table expiry points 

Possible to lock Scheduler 

Services to work with tasks and scheduler Schedule table 

Table with predefined actions on expiry points 

Statically defined tables. Run-time switching between tables allowed 

Can be cyclic or non-cyclic 

Uses counter to check expiry points 

Expiry points could be either absolute or relative to the counter 

Possible actions on expiry 
 - Set an event 
 - Activate a task directly Schedule table synchronization 

Supports 2 methods 
 - Implicit 
 - Done with counter attached to it (FlexRay/ TTP) 
 - Explicit 
 - Done with synchronization counter (additional functionality by OS ) 
 - Done by the user explicitly



Scheduling schemes 

Provides variety of scheduling schemes for OS applications 

The main schemes are 
 - Full pre-emptive 
 - Non pre-emptive 
 - Mixed pre-emptive 
 - Etc. ISRs and Types 

Triggered directly from hardware 

Highest priority than OS tasks 

No waiting inside ISR 

2 types 
 - ISR Category1 
 - Should not use OS services 
 - Least overhead on scheduling 
 - Finitet ime execution 
 - ISR Category2 
 - Can use OS services 
 - Can maintain its own stack 
 - The pre-empted task shall resume once ISR completes OS Resources 

Share resources with coordination 

Shared between tasks and ISRs also 

Waiting not allowed after acquiring resource 

No nesting of lock and unlock the resource with in the task/ ISR 

Resources has to be managed to get r id of 
 - Deadlocks 
 - Priority inversion 

Solution for issues with Resources 
 - Priority Ceiling Protocol 
 - Scheduler 

Types of Resources OS Protection 

Protection for OS objects 

OS objects assigned to OS applications 

Protection types 
 - Memory Protection 
 - Code, Data and St ack of an OS application 
 - No sharing of memory objects across OSapplicat ions 
 - Timing Protection 
 - Occurs at deadline missing 
 - Execution budget of Tasks and Cat 2 ISRs 
 - Lock budget for resources of tasks and ISRs 
 - Inter-arrival t ime of tasks 

Service Protection 
 - OS Service calls corrupting OS itself 
 - Invalid handles 
 - Wrong contexts 
 - Wrong resource locking/ unlocking 
 - Unwanted calls/ access across OS applications 

Hardware protection 
 - Highly useful in hardware mode (privileged/ non-privileged etc.) 
 - Protection for restricted hardware resources(peripherals, registers etc.) belonging to specific mode etc. 
 - Useful in non-trusted OS-Applications OS Hook functions 

Allows user defined actions at specific OS occasions 

Helps to trace 

Invoked by OS itself 

Higher priority than tasks and ISRs 

Follows standardized interface 

Hook functions available at 
 - System start-up 
 - System shutdown 
 - OSErrors 
 - OSProtection violations Service to SchM 

SchM is BSW Schedule Manager 

Handles BSW schedulable functions 

Provides services to handle critical regions of BSW modules 

Supports to all BSW module instances 

Task scheduling done by OS
Customize the OS
Access the ECU memory after deployment 

Measurement reads the data 

Calibration reads and edits the data 

Fine tune the data by calibrating to study application behavior 

Change the calibration data from external device 

Just by changing the calibrated data, the same software can be re-used to multiple vehicle variants/ platforms 

XCP facilitates all the above Protocol between a master and slave device 

Based on ASAM standards 

Provides 
 - Access the data synchronously/ asynchronously 
 - Data stimulation (for rapid prototyping) 
 - On-line memory calibration 
 - Flash programming 
 - FR/ CAN buses supported 
 - More optional features 
 - Available from AUTOSAR R4.x onwards FR and CAN buses are supported 

XCP messages sent/ received as per ASAM format 

Coding and De-coding of message done be respective Master and Salve 

XCP thru CAN 
 - XCP PDUs communication thru AUTOSAR CAN St ack 
 - 2 dedicated CAN IDs (Each one for Tx, Rx) need to be configured for XCP 
 - Messages decoded/ encoded by CCP module 

XCP thru FR 
 - XCP PDUs communication thru AUTOSAR FR St ack 
 - XCP messages on FR shall be event driven 
 - Multiple PDUs can be packed and sent in a single FR PDU
Abstracts BSW from application 

Allows parallel SW development 

Completely auto-generated for specific ECU 

VFB realized thru implementation of RTE 

Provides services to SW-Cs and to BSW to access the data/ services 

Provides data integrity and consistency mechanisms 

Runnables are scheduled by OS 

RTE events to synchronize the application needs 

Communication with in Runnables 

Implements VFB TRACE
Software Components 

Located above RTE 

Follows component style methodology 

RTE implements the interaction for SW-Cs 

SW-C is location independent, instantiated and highly re-usable 

SW-C description linked with RTE features



Compositions 

Ggroup of SW-Cs interconnected 

Delegation connectors used to connect to outside SW-Cs 

Is of SW-C type and can use all features of an atomic SW-C 

Communication possible with in composition 


Communication paradigms 

Provides communication schemes for SWCs 

The schemes communicate thru ports 

For inter-communication, RTE uses COM 

For intra-communication, RTE may use COM or implements on its own 

Schemes based on communication via data/ services 

2 Schemes for Inter-SWC and to BSW 
 - Sender -Receiver (S/ R) 
 - Client -Ser ver (C/ S) 

Scheme for Intra-SWC 
 - Inter-Runnable communication 


Sender-Receiver communication 

Transport of data from Sender to Receiver 

Single S/ R interface shall have many data elements. But data element transport will happen as per the contract with respective ports 

One way communication. No acknowledgement 

Filtering allowed on RTE level 

With LIFO fashion, both 1:N, N:1 are allowed 

With FIFO and queued fashion, both 1:N, N:1 are allowed 

For modes communication, its only 1:N is allowed
Client-Server communication 
Client requests for Ser ver’s services 

SW-C can be a Client and Ser ver 

A Client shall have multiple Ser vers 

Client types 
 - Synchr onous clients 
 - Asynchronous clients 

Only N:1 is allowed 

C/S interface shall have ‘n’ number of operations. Server offers the service based as per the contract with respective ports 

Server shall address serialization 

Two way communication 

Supports both LIFO and FIFO fashions 

Used for accessing Service SW-Cs
Inter-Runnable communication 

The local data of Runnable is abstracted with others 

The data can’t be shared directly 

RTE provides services to transport the data between Runnables 

Allowed for multiple instantiation also 

Ser vices to read and write the inter-runnable variables 

This communication doesn’t need 
 – Ports and Interfaces
Runnable entities 

The atomic SW-C is divided into small executables ‘Runnables’ 

Runnables use RTE and OS services 

Activated by RTE thru RTE events 

Server runnables doesn’t need activation if invoked concurrently. No OS Task mapping in this case 

Runnables are mapped to OS Tasks Runnable entity types 

Categorized based on its severity 

3 runnable types
Data accessing methods for Runnable entities 

Runnables access the data thru accessing methods 

Accessing methods related to communication schemes 

Queuing always be on receiver side 

Communication schemes 
 – Sender / Receiver 
 – Implicit access 
 – The updated data received automatically when Runnable starts 
 – The data updated is shared to other Runnables at the earliest of its termination 
 – Only non-blocking access 
 – Explicit access 
 – Runnable sends/ receives the data elements explicitly 
 – Based on Runnable types, the access could be blocking or non-blocking 
 – Client / Ser ver 
 – Synchronous access 
 – Blocking until Ser ver finishes the operation 
 – Asynchronous access 
 – Non-blocking Client . Ser ver notifies the completenessof operation
RTE Events 

To wait and resolve the dependencies 

Types of Events 
 - Timing event (T) 
 - DataReceivedEvent (DR) 
 - DatareceiveError Event (DRE) 
 - DataSendCompleteEvent (DSC) 
 - OperationInvokedEvent (OI) 
 - AsynchronousSer ver CallRetur nsEvent (ASCR) 
 - ModeSw ithEvent (MS) 


Runnable entities and RTE Events 

Runnable entities are activated by RTE events 

All events are associated with Runnables 

Release the runnables from WaitPoints
Mapping Data Elements to Signals 

Intra-communication of data handled by RTE 

Inter-communication of data is handled by COM 

Data elements are mapped to COM signals 

Simple data elements mapped to a normal COM signal 

Complex data elements mapped to Signal groups
AUTOSAR Services 

Deals with AUTOSAR Ser vice modules 

Application interacts with BSW services 

Interaction thru Ser vice ports 

Standar dized AUTOSAR interfaces shall be used 

C/ Sinterface is used 

Service BSW modules are 
 - NvM 
 - WdgM 
 - ComM 
 - EcuM 
 - DET and DEM 
 - DCM and FIM 
 - GPT 

SW-C description for the above modules shall be made and available to SW-Cs 

Service APIs invoked as simple Cfunctions leaving no overhead 


Service port mapping 

Service ports on both SW-C and Ser vice module 

Shall follow C/ Scommunication 

The mapping may be done with a simple Cbasics
Port Defined Argument Values 

How to have unique Ids thru out ECU software? 

How does SW-Cs know about DEM Fault/ NvM Block Ids? 

Hard code the Ids thru Client ports. Ids appended as arguments
Exclusive areas 

Guarantee data consistency 

Guard the data against concurrent accesses 

Mechanisms used are 
 - Sequential scheduling strategy 
 - Interrupt blocking strategy 
 - Usage of OSr esources 
 - Task blocking strategy 
 - Cooper ative Runnable placement strategy 
 - Etc. 

Services to access the cr itical sections of data 
 - Rte_Enter 
 - Rte_Exit 


Modes 

Start/ Stop runnables on entering/ exiting the modes 

SW-C user of these modes are called mode user 

Changes of modes notified to the mode user by the respective mode manager 

Mode user gets mode switch notifications upon changes
Mode ports and interface 

Mode managers in AUTOSAR 
 - ComM 
 - WdgM 
 - EcuM 

Need Ser vice mode ports to avail this feature 

Associated with ModeSw itchEvents 

Mode switch shall be synchronous/ asynchronous 

Mode Sw itch Interface supports only 1:N communication 


VFB Trace 

Trace the data with user defined functions 

Templates auto generated but functions has to be defined by user 

RTE services are configurable for hook functions 

Switch ON/ OFF facility for tracing 

Trace is also possible for Runnables 

COM signals can also be monitored on VFB 

OS is also traceable 


RTE Generation phases 

RTE is completely auto generated 

Two phases available for different project life cycle 

Phases 
 - Contract Phase 
 - Generation of SW-C header templates only 
 - General RTE types file 
 - Only SW-C description is needed
Generation Phase 

Complete ECU description files needed 

Complete generation of RTE 

Relationships with BSW modules are also generated
RTE Source and Header files 

RTE generation produces output files 
 - Rte_<SW-C>.h 
 - RTE API mapping 
 - Declaration of Runnables, RTE APIs 
 - Initial values 
 - Rte-Type.h 
 - Types of RTE needs and user defines types 
 - Limits of all types 
 - Rte_Cbk.h 
 - COM call-back declarations 
 - Rte_Cfg.h 
 - User definitions affecting the behavior of generated RTE 
 - Ex: Enable/ Disable VFB TRACE etc.
Rte_Hook.h 
 - Declarations of hook functions for Tracing 

Rte_Main.h 
 - Declarations of Rte_St art and Rte_St op functions 

Rte.h 
 - Fixed elements of RTE 

Rte.c 
 - RTE service definitions 
 - Definitions of OS tasks 
 - Definition of COM call-backs 
 - Definition of RAM variables for RTE 
 - Rte_St art and Rte_St op definitions 
 - Etc.
Calibration 

Adjust ECU SW to fit into specific vehicle needs 

Different mechanisms are provided 

Mechanisms are 
 - Measurement 
 - Measure what’s going on in the ECU 
 - Tools available to monitor the data 
 - Calibr ation 
 - Based on measurement data, data shall be modified 
 - Modify and fine tune the data suitable for specific project needs Offline and Online Calibration 

Methods based on how the calibration data is changed 

Types 
 - Offline 
 - Calibration data re-flashed while ECU is offline 
 - Online 
 - Calibration data modified while at ECU is online 
 - The calibration data is updated at runtime by external tester 
 - The new data written in to ECU at shutdown t ime Per-Instance Memory 

A specific memory needed for a specific SW-C instance 

Statically defined memory parts 

RTE service Rte_Pim to access the specific memory part of that instance 

Memory can be accessed by Runnables of that SW-C instance 

This memory is not sharable across other SW-Cs
Calibration parameters 

Design Calibr ation parameters in AUTOSAR 
 - Design as Calibr ation SW-Cs 
 - Only have PPorts of type Cal-Pr m 
 - Uses Cal-Pr m interface 
 - Just provides the Cal-Pr m data to other SW-Cs 
 - Can’t have runnables, events etc…No internal behavior 
 - Accessthe Cal-Pr m data thru Rte_CalPr m service
Internal Calibration parameters with in SW-Cs 

Defined in SW-C description 

Can be only used with in SW-C 

Two types 
 - Per-Instance 
 - Separate for each instance of SW-C 
 - Shared 
 - Shared across all instances of SW-C 

RTE provides Rte_CDat a service to access the data Calibration methods 

Two types of calibration 
 - Offline calibration 
 - No changes to calibration parameters at run t ime 
 - All calibration parametersare read from ROM directly 
 - Re-flashed in ROM directly 
 - RTE just shares the info by reading from ROM 
 - Online calibration 
 - RTE allocates RAM to these calibration parameters 
 - Changes to parameters at runtime thru external tools 
 - The latest data written back to ECU at shutdown 
 - The new data shall be read from next journey onwards
The interoperability of solutions requires a high quality standard. AUTOSAR has defined a process to ensure such high quality when changes are introduced in a revision or when new features are introduced in new minor or major releases. 

 AUTOSAR is also continuously monitoring the interoperability of AUTOSAR tool chain solutions and provide acceptance tests for the Classic Platform which enable an early assessment of suppliers’ basic software solutions in a development process. 

 AUTOSAR’s Adaptive Platform is designed for interoperability with other software platforms. By using dynamic service oriented communication patterns, applications can easily exchange information with for example infotainment systems.
New use-cases require the development of the Adaptive Platform. 
 Highly automated driving where the driver temporarily and/or partially passes responsibility for driving to the vehicle. This requires for instance communication with traffic lights, the use of high-performance micro-controllers and computing. 

 Car-2-X applications require interaction to vehicles and off-board systems. That means the system has to provide secure on-board communication, support of cross domain computing platforms, smartphone integration, integration of non-AUTOSAR systems, and so on. 

 Cloud based services will require dedicated means for security such as secure cloud interaction and emergency vehicle preemption. They will enable remote and distributed services, for instance remote diagnostics, in-field flashing, repair and exchange handling.
The Classic Platform is the first choice for deeply embedded ECUs with high demands regarding safety and deterministic execution. It targets small and medium sized microcontrollers. 

 The Adaptive Platform supports adaptive deployment of applications and interaction with Classic Platform and non-AUTOSAR systems. It targets high performance microcontrollers.
Updates and improvements of the standard will be introduced by future versions of AUTOSAR. Corrections are handled by a change management process and are provided as revisions of the existing releases. New features are matured in concepts which are introduced only in new releases. New minor releases accept only backward compatible features whereas major releases could introduce non backward compatible features. The AUTOSAR versions are numbered according to this scheme: andlt;major releaseandgt;.andlt;minor releaseandgt;.andlt;revisionandgt;. 

 AUTOSAR’s standard Adaptive Platform makes use of agile development methods. That means functions and updates are developed in sprints. There is a regular release cycle to introduce those functions and updates into the market.
Yes, AUTOSAR provides application interfaces for Body, Chassis, Pedestrian and Occupant Safety, and Powertrain applications.
One of the main requirements of AUTOSAR is to assure the interoperability with legacy software. This will enable the re-use of existing, non-AUTOSAR compliant software, e.g. drivers. The most obvious way to reach this integration is using a Complex Driver as a wrapper around the non-AUTOSAR compliant software.
The acceptance of AUTOSAR will depend heavily on processing and memory requirements. The modular architecture of AUTOSAR provides a scalable solution where users or implementers can discard modules or configure out features of the basic software in order to limit the memory and performance impacts in micro controllers.
Using and implementing existing standards is given the highest priority. 

 This has been the case since the beginning of the project. For example AUTOSAR’s operating system and communication stack were based on OSEK, and the AUTOSAR System Template was based on ASAM. Furthermore AUTOSAR introduces support for new standard when there is a market need for the automotive industry. 

 As AUTOSAR members also participate to the elaboration of other standard, it has been possible to provide, with AUTOSAR, and standardized software solution to implement other standard as soon as they are published. For instance functional safety mechanisms were added to support ISO 26262, and the partial networking or Can FD concepts were introduced to support new versions of ISO 11898.
